importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed, marking the beginning of the agreement under which Hamas was required to return deceased hostages to Israel.
The date when two coffins containing the remains of deceased hostages were reported to have crossed into Israel, advancing the timeline of the ceasefire implementation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe within which Hamas was supposed to return all deceased hostages as per the Trump administration's ceasefire agreement.
The prolonged and complex effort to recover and identify all deceased hostages, indicating the challenge of recovery due to war damage and logistical barriers.

keyTakeAways: Two coffins with apparent remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transported from Gaza into Israel by Hamas under the terms of the US-proposed ceasefire deal.

The Israeli military and Ministry of Health confirmed the bodies arrived at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification, with 14 and 15 deceased hostages now accounted for under the agreement.
Hamas had previously returned 13 bodies, all of which were formally identified, including Sergeant Major Tal Haimi.
One of the earlier bodies handed over was not identified as an Israeli hostage, suggesting possible misidentification or difficulties in recovery.
Israeli intelligence believes Hamas may not be able to locate and recover all remaining dead hostages due to rubble and war damage.
The US Vice President, JD Vance, emphasized the difficulty of the recovery process, noting that some bodies are buried under rubble and that it is not going to happen overnight.
The ceasefire agreement was reaffirmed by both Hamas and Israel after a reported attack that killed two IDF soldiers, though both sides accused each other of violations.
The Israeli military urged the public to refrain from speculation and to wait for official identification to be communicated to families.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation-state in the Middle East involved in the ongoing conflict with Hamas and the recipient of the transferred hostage remains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is the country receiving the remains of deceased hostages under the ceasefire agreement, and the primary stakeholder in the humanitarian and political implications of the body returns.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant group and the main adversary of Israel, responsible for the initial capture of hostages and now acting under the ceasefire agreement to return them.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is directly involved in the transfer of the coffins, with its compliance or non-compliance under the ceasefire agreement being central to the article's narrative.

namedEntities.name: Al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The armed wing of Hamas responsible for military actions and, in this context, for the transfer of the coffins.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Al-Qassam Brigades is cited as having announced the scheduled transfer of the two coffins, indicating operational involvement in the ceasefire process.

namedEntities.name: Red Cross
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international humanitarian organization involved in the handling and transfer of the coffins from Gaza to Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Cross is noted as having previously held custody of the coffins before handing them over to Israeli forces, indicating a role in humanitarian logistics.

namedEntities.name: US Vice President JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A US political official visiting Israel and commenting on the ceasefire implementation and recovery efforts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance’s remarks on the difficulty of recovering bodies and the fragility of the ceasefire underscore US involvement and diplomatic concerns.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The US government, which brokered the ceasefire deal and set the framework for hostage returns.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration’s agreement and ongoing efforts to implement the ceasefire are foundational to the context and legitimacy of the hostage return process.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution responsible for the identification and investigation of the deceased hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This institution is where the bodies are being identified, making it a central site in the humanitarian and investigative process.

namedEntities.name: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli military personnel, one of the 13 deceased hostages formally identified under the ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His identification marks a significant milestone in the process, showing progress in identifying and returning the deceased.

namedEntities.name: IDF (Israel Defense Forces)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The military force of Israel responsible for receiving and securing the coffins and overseeing the return process.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is the primary actor in receiving, transporting, and securing the coffins, and in communicating with the public and families.

namedEntities.name: Israel Security Agency (ISA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key intelligence and security body in Israel that co-issued a statement about the coffins' arrival.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ISA's involvement in the announcement shows the integration of intelligence and security operations in the hostage recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Ministry of Health (Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli governmental body that confirmed the arrival of the bodies and the work underway at the forensic institute.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ministry of Health confirms the logistics and medical handling of the bodies, emphasizing public health and family welfare aspects.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Israeli military reported that two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages crossed into Israel from Gaza under the terms of a US-proposed ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025. The bodies were handed over by Hamas, with prior custody held by the Red Cross, and are now being identified at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine. This marks the 14th and 15th deceased hostages to be returned since the ceasefire began, following the return of 13 previously identified bodies, including Sergeant Major Tal Haimi. Hamas has admitted that significant challenges — including rubble and missing bodies — make recovery difficult, and one prior body was misidentified, raising concerns about accuracy. The Israeli military and public are urged to wait for official identification. US Vice President JD Vance emphasized the difficulty of the recovery process, noting that some bodies are buried under rubble and that the task will take time. The broader implications of the ceasefire deal’s implementation, including Hamas’s compliance and the return of all deceased hostages, remain under active scrutiny.
title: Israeli Military Says Two Coffins Said to Contain Hostages’ Bodies Cross Into Israel
